headline: Trump slams alleged FBI surveillance of his campaign
subHeadline: President comments for the first time on camera about an FBI informant communicating with associates of his campaign; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.sentences: We love you, but you're cranky today. So anyway, I just want to say, this is a rare moment when I agree with you, because I'm a regular Starbucks customer. And but the thing is, Greg, I go in and I get upset if I can't use the bathroom because it's occupied.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Or someone is in there for hours. But I also get upset when I can't find a place to sit or even stand, because guess what? It's not homeless people. But it's oftentimes young people. They've got their computers. They've got this and that. Now, I will say that -- So I get upset. But then I feel like, you know what? I am a privileged little snot, because my wife said to me and other people have said to me that Starbucks intentionally created a culture where they're a coffee shop. They are the so-called third place where you can meet your friends, where you can have debates, where you can work. And then all of a sudden, you say, "Well, but that guy looks kind of threatening or that guy looks like he's poor, and he can't be in here." Well, that's a contradiction. And then all of a sudden, you do get involved in, are those two guys who are asking to use the bathroom just bums or are they just two businessmen?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Hello, hello, hello. Two words. Dunkin' Donuts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: There goes the sources (ph). Let me tell you, if they're going to act like this with the nonsense, so no one's trying to discriminate. Are you buying something in there? Do you have something you would like to purchase to stimulate the economy, or do you just want to come in and clogged the toilet and take all the tables? I've had it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: By the way, it's -- Brian, you can't -- imagine doing this at any restaurant, where you walk in and go, "I'm just going to hang out." You can't. You go to a Greek diner in midtown, they'll throw you out out.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: In another language.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But it's a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I will say this. This one, is this your best block in a long time. You're down three different roads, and I'm totally in -- I can't beat this. But I would say I -- fundamentally, I cannot use somebody's bathroom or get changed to pay a -- to pay a toll unless I buy something from that store. I just know that that's it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Your parents taught you that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: you just know it --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Isn't it courteous? Right? If you go in to use the 7-Eleven bathroom, and you know, buy a Snickers.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: By the way, the Starbucks -- the Starbucks and the Dunkin' Donuts have something in common. Their bathrooms are way too big. You can land a helicopter in them. You just need a small bathroom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I like the big bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: You do?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: There is going to be a lawsuit, just like, you know, somebody is going to be injured or stabbed and then that's it for this.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Or you woke up. Or you're going to have to make our own coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, Brian, there's somebody over here. This ain't no "FOX & Friends." All right? Dana, this is actually a failure of society and a way to figure out what to do with the homeless. This is, like, our Band-Aid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, a couple things. One, this falls into my P.R. law that every overreaction will cause an equal or greater overreaction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That should be in your book.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And this was going to -- I'll write a new book, maybe. Put this back in there. I am for better and more public restrooms. OK? It doesn't have to be at somebody's private business. But if this private business decides that this is what it wants to do this, OK, knock yourselves out. But I would rather go to Dunkin'.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. There you go. I think we solved one of the world's greatest problems. Like Dunkin' Donuts. Maybe they will send us some stuff.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Before the show is over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I would like to make a suggestion for some Febreze in the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It just covers it up, Kimberly. Should bosses crack down on employees' obsessive cell phone use? Let's debate next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: New studies are revealing some shocking information about just how addicted we all are to our cell phones. A recent one finds that the average person touches, pokes, pinches and swipes their phone --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What do you mean, pinches?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- over 2,600 times a day. It's unbelievable. Because of this, one CEO is banning them in meetings, and others are trying to limit their employees' phone use. Now, we sit here at this desk. And there are four cell phones on the desk. Let me just tell you --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And an iPad.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So what do you think, Kimberly? It's a good idea to ban him?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, it makes sense. Right?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: It does.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Because then you just can't reach out. You can't touch them. You can't, you know, resist the temptation. I don't know. I just like to get things done, organize, make lists, like always updating things. So I'm always trying to get something done. I don't like downtime too much. But yes, I think if you're in a meeting and pay attention, et cetera, then maybe it's like a good little line in a meeting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Brian, in fact, picking up on what Kimberly said, according to the studies, you have a lower level of cognitive performance if your mobile phone is on the desk.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: This is the biggest issue in America today, because everyone has a phone. No matter how rich or poor you are, everyone's got a phone, and it's distracting. It's like, hey, you guys are OK, but the people here are more important.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: And I think this boss is doing a great thing in all of them, he or she is, by allowing us -- making us put this away, so I have no choice. I will get in trouble if I put it away.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: By the way, you have two, all the time. On "FOX & Friends." All the time when I used to fill in for you.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Can I just be a commentator and not my personal life?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Your personal ---

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: But it is -- but it is a problem, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I'll telling you, I would just wonder how many times I would use it, any of us would use it if we weren't in the news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Dana, so I learned a new word today. Nomo-phobia. Which means no mobile phones make you afraid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They like their --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You want your phone. You want to know what's going on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I would say, if you're a recent graduate and you've just got a new job in the great new economy, if you want to get promoted, start today on the first job, do not take your cell phone to any meetings. Don't take it out. And you will be noticed, and it will be recognized.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This is a very good tip for a minute.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: This is just going great, this block.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'll put that in my yew book, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg, do you disagree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. I -- there's research that shows, like, the brain's function is to be attentive. And you can try this anytime you want. Try to pay attention to more than one thing. It's impossible. It's why we get obsessed over things. If somebody introduces a thought into your head, you will think about it and you will not be able to think about anything else. You can say you're listening to your spouse while you're watching a game, but you're actually switching. It's imperceptible. But you're actually switching, and so you're actually missing out on important things. And this is actually pretty deadly. If you look at the -- as the stuff has come out with driving and texting, it's probably one of the most dangerous combinations you're going to find. And I don't know what -- what the numbers, but it's pretty close to --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What about you, show hosting and on Twitter?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Freaking out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I do it during break so I don't have to talk to you people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now we know how you really feel.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Can we stay on commercial break?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, we have "One More Thing" to make you laugh. That's next om "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing." We're going to skip Brian until the last one. You get to go first.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, thanks.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Anyway --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Payback.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what? Life is full of surprises, and yesterday I got a happy one. It was a very proud moment when I learned that my biography of former Supreme Court justice Thurgood Marshall was named one of the 40 best biographies of all time --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- by BookClub.com.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So take a look at this classic C-SPAN interview I did 20 years ago, in 1998, when the book came out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I had a real privilege, Brian. I got to interview Marshall for a six-month period in 1989. This was at the end of his career, end of his life. It was a rich time, and one in which he was willing to talk. I felt -- you know, it's been a great gift for me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So the book has continued to steadily sell and was reissued for the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board. So for me, just on a personal basis, let me just say thank you and it's a thrill to be among America's greatest biographers. I can't believe it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm glad I could help you with that book.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The book's in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's really impressive, Juan. Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. I've got one. Too bad Jesse isn't here, because he would have been impressed with this one. All right. Mary Sedgwick, she's been legally blind since 2003, and she recently got the chance to see her guide dog for the first time, thanks to a pair of high-tech glasses.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And she shared the video of her very emotional moment. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: MARU SEDGWICK, LEGALLY BLIND
utterances.sentences: Lucy! Look at your eyes, Lucy! Oh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, those of us who are animal lovers -- and I don't mean MS-13 -- animal lovers will love that. She put in an online post that "There are no words to describe how I felt when I saw the face of my beloved family and friends and the beautiful soulful eyes of Lucy for the first time." She was a medical student, and she was -- she had dreams of being a doctor. In her fourth year at school, that was when her blindness began. But she says now, with these new glasses she hopes to return to work in the medical field. And we wish her a lot of luck.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This is excellent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's a very moving moment. Very happy for her. So I have a very cute "One More Thing." And it's about seven Glenpool firefighters. And they welcomed new babies all within one year. Seven of Oklahoma's bravest not only battle the blazes but also change diapers and make bottles.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: In less than a year, seven out of the 20 from this Glenpool Fire Department in Glenpool, Oklahoma, as it turns out, became new dads. And so they decided to commemorate the special occasion with group photos that came from one of the firefighters' wives. So they waited for the last child to be born. So they go -- oldest is 15 months, youngest is four weeks. Obviously, was probably pretty difficult to get all those babies to be looking in the same direction at the same time. So congratulations to them. And God bless their families.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a great story.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So cute, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Now for actual news.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Cable News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Cable News." All right, as you know, CNN has been in a lot, a lot of ratings trouble. God knows what's going to happen to them. So they've decided -- they've decided -- CNN has decided to bring back "Crossfire" for the third time. And here's a clip. I've got a preview.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Which one's Tucker?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Here we go. Here we go. I'm telling you, you put this on at 8 p.m., CNN, you're going to get huge ratings. So don't keep it at 5. Put it at 8.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's not going to work, because they don't have Tucker Carlson.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Well, let's talk greatness. Let's talk soccer. First off, Cristiano Rinaldo, he is the best player, maybe, in the world today. Everyone laughed when they looked at his bust. They said, "What are you doing? Are you mocking him? And I thought that was as lowest they can go. And now comes -- now comes Brandi Chastain. Remember Brandi Chastain, one of the finest women soccer players ever? Eight-eight caps. Excuse me, 192 caps, on the national team from '88 to 2004.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We don't know what that means.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: That means playing in the national -- in the national game. Well, she's so great, they put her into the Bay Area Sports Hall of Fame. That's the good news.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: But look at the picture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, that's not her.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: That is her. Sometimes it's better not to be great if that's how you're going to be depicted for all time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like, you could draw her better on the back of your folder. Than that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: People say that might be Babe Ruth on a bad day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Brandi Chastain is a beautiful woman.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's not very nice.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: She demands better.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's not very nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They should redo that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: It's so great not to be great because no one will ever do that for me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Brian Kilmeade and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." President Trump addressing two major issues today while meeting with the president of South Korea, including his summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. We will get to his comments on that in a moment. But first, the president is commenting for the first time on camera about an FBI informant communicating with associates of his campaign.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: A lot of people are saying they had spies in my campaign. I hope there weren't, frankly. But some man got paid based on what I read in the newspapers. And, I think the Department of Justice wants to get down to it, and I can tell you congress does. If they had spies in my campaign, during my campaign for political purposes, that would be unprecedented in the history of our country.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Senator Chuck Schumer is saying these moves to learn more about the FBI informant are an attempt to obstruct the special counsel Russia investigation.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: While an investigation is open and active, demands for oversight are tantamount to interference. Especially, when the folks demanding the information are the most biased, irresponsible actors, a man like Devin Nunes, who I hear privately for my Republican colleagues, they think he's off the deep end.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, please.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Off the deep end? I don't know. There's all sorts of stuff going on. OK. So, here's a question, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The president has the power as the chief executive officer, the President of the United States, commander-in-chief, to declassify all of these documents.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Would just that be a good idea to get over it?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm so glad I was the first question because I think it's fascinating and there are a lot of people calling for it, saying, you know what, let's just show complete transparency, declassify the documents and put it all out there. So, there isn't some of this leaking this and leaking that, putting bits and pieces out. It will actually show the whole framework, and exactly what happened, and who did what. And maybe that's what the American people need at this point instead of like a drip from the faucet coming down. Put it all out there, and then we'll know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Brian?

utterances.speaker: BRIAN KILMEADE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you for that or you're not for that?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: A legal expert will say that that is a huge mistake because there might be somebody inside Russia that we're dealing with right now that are helping us today. I would say this, if you're doing a counterterror operation, why don't you stop with the people -- why don't you start with the people that are actually trying to infiltrate, the Russians. Show some guts. Go over to Russian and ask them what's going on, or use your contacts to find out what they have to say. Instead, you're going up to these ancillary people on the Trump campaign, and nobody says they're major players, and trying to find out what somebody might have whispered to them in a drunken conversation. And for people to say, like, Chuck Schumer, it's irresponsible to allow these people to find out who has infiltrated your campaign. That's because it's not your campaign.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: If someone infiltrated Chuck Schumer's campaign, they wouldn't say, oh, wait a second, the FBI is allowed to have their sources. I don't blame President Trump for being outraged, to find out what was going on in -- or not going on with this Cambridge attorney -- excuse me, the Cambridge professor. I don't blame him for finding out Carter Page, Cloves and Caputo, what was happening with these guys and the names that came out. Why wouldn't you be curious about that? It would be illogical for him not to be. The only thing at stake is his presidency and how long he stays.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, OK, Juan, let me ask you then about -- the idea that if the deep state, if we're calling it that, was so determined to hurt President Trump, what about the Democrats feeling like they actually hurt Clinton more because they kept the FBI investigation into the Trump campaign under wraps, but were more forthcoming in the press about Clinton.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, that's -- you know, kind of contradicts the whole flow of what you're seeing now coming from the president and conservative media, that the campaign that was hurt by the FBI was the Clinton campaign. There was no damage done to President Trump's campaign. In fact, I mean, there's some people who are arguing that because they were conducting counterintelligence operations, as opposed to a criminal investigation, they were actually trying to protect and try to act as a buffer to keep the Russian influence out of all the campaign, including the Trump campaign. But I think what you're seeing now in response to your question, Dana, is an effort by the president, and I think it's unprecedented to sort of weaponized an investigation into the investigation into him.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But isn't weaponising, Greg, if it's the Justice Department saying, OK, look, we have an inspector general that everyone seems to support, Michael Horowitz, because he's a fair guy, and he says he'll take a look at this as well. So, can we just let that play out? But it could be months.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: What is Russian for Mexican standoff? That's what we have right now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Standusky.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go. It's five versus five. Look, I actually see what -- the question that you just asked Juan. I see the opposite. Hillary's investigation was put in the press to help her. Remember what Comey said, got to get this out of the way because if she wins and this comes out, we look really bad, so let's help her. Trump was kept under wraps because they wanted to catch him.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's why you see -- why is this one known, why -- you can look at it anyway.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or because they thought he wasn't going to win.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's true. But it is -- going back to the Laurel and the Yanny, which I will never give up, the fact is, which collusion story now is more persuasive, all right. So let's take the Yanny, which is the Trump collusion story, it's been going on for 18 months. We haven't found a damn thing. Then you look at the Laurel of collusion, FBI, Hillary, Democrats, the British spy, one informant, maybe two informants inserted in the campaign. If you compare these two sides, you've got one where there's a meeting with a woman about the Magnitsky Act, that's something like that, right? Oh, that's Earth shattering. Meanwhile, you've got a dossier paid for by Hillary. You've got an informant, maybe two, placed as a favor. You have the press playing it down. You have the dossier contents leaked. If we start comparing these things, one is making a hell a lot more sense as collusion than the other.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you're going down what I would call the rabbit hole, because there's a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We've been going down -- Juan, we've been going down this rabbit hole now for 18 months. Excuse me if I find another rabbit hole to go down.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: The Washington Post, the New York Times on Thursday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: . they began to leak out information, maybe to get ahead.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: . to let us know that there's a rabbit hole out there that you're about to go down. So, let me give you an idea what at the bottom. Here's what I would say, I think Alan Dershowitz nailed it when he said I don't care of it's the '98 Clinton investigation, now the 2017-16 Clinton-Trump campaign. You will never get to the bottom of it as long as there's a -- it is this type of operation. We've got to go back to the 9/11 commission to get answers. Publish the results because it did not affect the election. You should just find out what's wrong to stop the next problem, because this horse is out of the barn and no one even saw the horse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think there's a problem here. First of all, this latest effort to somehow say I hereby demand, like he is not president, but he's some authoritarian ruler. I hereby demand.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That to me -- well, what happened, Greg? Immediately, Rod Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general said OK, I'm going to do this. And the question becomes is he simply trying to appease the president or is he following orders?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're obsessing over words. I hereby -- OK, it sounds like King Arthur's castle.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It sure does. It sounds like a king, not the President of the United States. Because you are normalizing this kind of abuse of power while the president is under a special.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But what I think everyone is missing is not who's right or wrong, it affected -- Trump is just trying to run an election. He hires his foreign policy council, then he got on the back of a Cheerios box. And they go out and they do their thing, and somehow they are targeted by this informant.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the government told the Trump campaign the Russians are going to try to do this.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. They knew. And then -- whatever -- the people that are on the campaign. We know that they did have these contacts, Mickey Mouse, whatever, drunken things, but those weren't disclosed, Kimberly, so then you have this question. And I agree the Laurel and Yanny thing. But I just don't understand if we ask -- the house Republicans were asking -- 12 house Republicans are asking for a second special counsel. If you want to make this so much longer and lead this show every day for the next ten months on this issue, that will be a good way to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's still unfair because you're saying, oh, we'll keep going with this other investigation and we'll keep saying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying release all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . release all the documents tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But, you should also say, well, if they think this is just as important, then it's just as important.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Then, it's just a finish. So, we concur on that, that they should just release all the documents, because I think then we're going to try -- you know, get another special counsel. Let's have the I.G. report come out. Let's have the documents released, it certainly within the power and authority of the President of the United States to do so. So, it's not like he's trying to hide something. He's saying let's put it all out there. And as it relates to any people that we have operating in the theater that can be compromise, you can redact their names. It's not like you just turn over there's nothing. There are protections in place. This legal expert.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What about North Korea?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Go for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Knock yourself out. Here listen to the president on North Korea.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: There're certain conditions that we want, and I think we'll get those conditions, and if we don't come we don't have the meeting. North Korea has a chance to be a great country, and it can't be a great country under these circumstances that they're living right now. For a short period of time, we've been dealing with North Korea and it's been a, you know, good experience.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, the president basically saying we're tapping the brakes on this thing, Kim Jong-un, and we are not just gonna come over there for a show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. No, this is purely negotiation tactics. Look, you know, he -- you know, if time is not in his favor, the deadline moves. He introduces and reintroduces key things that we've heard before, which is like you never know how it's going to go. You never know until the last minute. When you're buying an apartment or a car, you never know when somebody is gonna walk out, they might walk out once, twice, three times. And the one thing that's important was the tone, which is it's not the end of the world if it doesn't happen now because it's going to happen. There's a key thing in this. He's dangling the carrot while holding the stick, while remaining optimistic and promising, while also unloading flattery on everybody. This is his unique tool set.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's clear that it was China that turn things, I believe, that week before. Next thing you know, Kim Jong-un in his unitard shows up on that beach in China. And they're staring at the ocean and it comes back, and next thing you know he's got a brand new tone and he's upset about the military exercises. Clearly something happened a week before. Fine. But, I was surprised it didn't happen earlier, but they're on a one-way tractor coming toward some type of legitimate summit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I guess it could still happen. But maybe June 12 is a little bit too soon.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's probably a little bit, you know, aggressive. And so, the president is doing what he should do which is letting the American people know don't have your hopes up that perhaps it's not going to happen June 12, but it doesn't mean that it's not going to happen because that's coming up pretty quickly. And the point is to just rush to a summit, but to get to it in the right way and make sure that some of the terms and ideas are specified and there is some accord.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I saw that coming.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Here we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I saw that coming. Root against the president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say, Kimberly, if he wasn't acting on the basis of impulse and I'm going to just prove that I'm the only president who can do this, George W. Bush, Bill Clinton, Barack -- they couldn't do it, but I'm going to do it. Maybe they would have thought, oh, maybe we should set the terms before we agree to a meeting. That's what most president.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're just too eager to criticize his efforts to try to get to a peaceful solution. My point is there're bumps along the way. China is playing a big part in it, so it's a very complex situation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct. That's why you saw other president say giving this guy a meeting is a reward for him. He wants that international stature. We don't give that unless you are very clear you're going to do away with your nuclear weapons. Clearly, that has become the point of contention.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That approach in the past has not garnered favorable results, has it?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I do think the pressure in this is one issue -- he's never even been in a rally without saying maybe it will happen. Maybe it won't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He never lied about this.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Last week he didn't tweet out anything derogatory.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Inflammatory.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: . inflammatory, derogatory. He went after Brennan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is behind the scenes. This is China that's involved in -- yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And North Korea has some nerve. They asked one of their new demands is that the South Koreans have to return 13 defectors that worked in a restaurant in China back to North Korea. Please, I hope that doesn't happen.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. Next, Democratic hysteria over President Trump's animals remark intensifies, details next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. You like that, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's been almost a week since some media took President Trump's animals comment on the murderous MS-13 out of context, but some Democrats still can't get over it. Among those railing against the president is the Oakland, California, mayor who you recall tipped off illegals to help them escape ICE raids.

utterances.speaker: LIBBY SCHAAF, MAYOR OF OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA
utterances.utterance: I believe that this president's language is racist. It is fearmongering and it is trying to distract the American people from the job that elected officials are supposed to do, and that's to improve the lives of the people that we represent, instead of casting blame and dispersion against a very vulnerable population.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, as liberals criticize Trump for his language, a Harvard law professor was forced to apologize for this comment he made about the president.

utterances.speaker: LAURENCE TRIBE, HARVARD LAW PROFESSOR
utterances.utterance: You can't be the boy who cried wolf and expect to have a viable impeachment power. You can't use it over and over again against the same president.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRIBE
utterances.utterance: If you're going to shoot him, you've got to shoot to kill.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Greg, so a lot of incendiary, inflammatory comments, in particular the comment about the president being racist it's just totally out of line.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: These are both examples of metaphors, and if you're not going to take the word -- if you're going to take the word animal literally, then you have to take shoot to kill literally. I don't take either literally. It was an unfortunate choice of words. And I'm very pro-metaphor, and I think journalists should be pro-metaphor.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You ran on that platform.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I did. But I love this.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's still running.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right now, an MS-13 member just got a 40-year prison sentence for conspiracy, which included the murder of a 15-year-old boy. You know what his name was? Ten bucks, I'll give you ten bucks. What was his nickname?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: The animal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Animal. So, I think Trump is right. His nickname was animal and he killed a kid. The thing is I think any time the Democrats are standing up for a murderous drug gang, it's a bad day for the Democrats. It really is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you think this is about somebody standing up for MS-13?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That just proves how off you are on this, because what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not evidence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . is the president who is referring to people as animals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Gang members, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, he has -- he has managed.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, look, they're so friendly and innocent. Look at the pictures.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . most immigrants, especially illegal immigrants.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So they're all gang members. So you're saying all immigrants are gang members?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait, let me finish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Go for it. You're digging your own hole.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Most immigrants are not bad. They're hardworking people who come to this country with great dreams, willing to make tremendous sacrifices in order to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . American family.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No one disagrees with that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're conflating that with gang members.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: President Trump, at the campaign level and now as president, has continually made the case that, oh, you know, these illegal -- they come in here, rapists, thieves, and now animals? No wonder people are upset.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: There are times the president makes mistakes. This was not one of them.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Correct.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: This -- I was clear, I've watched it. He clearly was talking about the gang members. He was not talking about anyone who crosses the border. And, in particular, these guys cut out the body organs of people when they're still alive. There's about 10,000 in the United States that prefer instead of shooting you, to use a machete, because they want the blood.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that typical of most immigrants?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the point. He was calling them animals. My goodness.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Juan, there are times the president is does not say what he means. This was not one of those times.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the thing is that having long engaged in demonizing, if not dehumanizing immigrants, when he said this, it struck people as, my God, it's a wink and a nod again to his base. Oh, let's hate on immigrants.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no. So, basically, because he was right there, he must have been wrong another time. That's how they justify hoaxes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Here's Dana.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I just think that people need to pick their battles a little bit more. Be more strategic and smart about picking your battles. This is not one that I would -- in fact, I think the Democrats could have gone a step further, like outflank the president and be tougher on MS-13 that he is. Like, try that maneuver next time because this one didn't work.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There's an interesting column today in the Wall Street Journal by Gerry Seib about immigration, and what he said was we have declining birthrates, we have needs and so many industries for workers right now, but we're not having a discussion about how immigrants, in fact, could add to our economic activity, to the vibrancy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a great discussion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When somebody is calling immigrants animals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it's not if you misidentify that is calling immigrants animals. He was calling gang members animals.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't call anybody animals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, what about Hitler? Hitler is not an animal?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Answer this question, Juan, is Hitler an animal?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, how about the worst criminal in the United States? Is he an animal? No, he's a human being.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you evaded the question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you're trying to playing games. I'm just trying to be.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, we're not. We're not playing games. I'm a product of immigrants.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: His nickname was animal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Listen, the president and Americans, we appreciate the value and work of immigrants and families that come over here to be part of a productive, law-abiding society.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Dana, you stop me if I'm wrong here. Two-thirds of the immigration debate, we can actually agree on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's the one-third we can't get past.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want you deported, Kilmeade.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Back to "Fox & Friends."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If everybody could agree on MS-13 being the bad actors.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, we're not agreeing on that because that's what this whole thing has turned into because people chose.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Language.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . to go after the president on one particular thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're never going to get an immigration.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree. I don't think you're going to find too many defenders of MS-13.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're called the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Do you really want to call human beings animals?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, why not.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: If the shoe fits -- by the way, that's the nicest thing I've heard gang members and MS-13 called. Come in to one of my courtrooms and you'll see what they do. They're called savages and everything else.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He nickname himself animal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right. And one of them self identifies named animal. OK. So, let's not get caught up in this little vanilla biscuit, oh, you know, semantic gymnastics. You know what he meant. He said it. He wasn't talking about hardworking immigrants and that's that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But that other debate is a good one to have if we could actually.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We do have. We've done it on The Five many times.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Ahead of midterms, Democrats are now mimicking President Trump's winning campaign strategy. Are they a party out of ideas? Next.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We are going to drain the swamp. We need to drain the swamp and we're going to do it and we are doing it. Drain the swamp.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Hey, it worked for President Trump in 2016. Remember drain the swamp. Now, it appears Democratic leaders are trying to hijack one of his signature phrases, his slogan, for example.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: The American people are confronted when the most compromise, corrupt administration in history. Instead of delivering on its promise to drain the swamp, President Trump has become the swamp.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: The swamp has never been more foul or more fetid than under this president.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: As a tribute to Senator Schumer, I'm going to move my tie.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And looked down at your paper, so we only see the top of your head.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, deputy DNC chairperson, Keith Ellison -- OK, I'll call him a chairman, debuts a bizarre new anti-Trump song over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I want to be called a stable genius. I just call my best friend, Vladimir Putin. Vladimir Putin. My buddy, Vladimir Putin. You can stop asking about covfefe, that's just Russian for porn. Stormy Daniels. I miss you, Stormy Daniels.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Democrats may want to rethink these type of tactics, or they may want to embrace them, because a new CBS poll shows the midterm, generic ballot advantage for them, that was in double digits, is now down to single digits, under five in most polls. Joining us now is Dana Perino, ignored in the last block because I believe you're undervalued.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because you, Chatty Cathy, are talking too much. And this one, and this one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Can I finish?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Dana -- Dana, what do you think about this, these two instances of extreme behavior?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is a strange thing. The Laurel and Yanny thing might get old, but I feel like it's been really instructive over the past week to understand how people can see things so differently. So when Keith Ellison does that performance in front of that crowd, they love it. OK? They love it. When President Trump is at his rallies, his people love it. And either -- if you look at it from the other side, like, "I can't stand it. I can't stand it." I do think that the Democrats are a little bit in trouble. Just today, four of the House seats removed from -- from the Democrat position to either solid Republican or lean Republican or to toss-up, where it had been in the Democratic camp. If we're talking razor-thin margins for who's going to control the majorities in the fall, I think that the Republicans are definitely on the right track.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's interesting, because you know, it's so far away. We didn't have the generic ballot. It's almost giving the House away to the Democrats already. Can they hold the Senate? But now things have changed a bit. But what they're pointing to, Juan, is Scott Pruitt has had some problems.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Ben Carson has had really nice furniture. Tom Price made some bad travel decisions, lost his job. I don't know if that's a swamp.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about Mick Mulvaney saying he'll meet with people who are donors? How about --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That was taken out of context.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about Michael Cohen --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think Broidy, that story today was big.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. How about -- how about Michael Cohen just doing business with companies in order to buy the pay-for-play access to the president. I think he's the president's lawyer.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: (UNINTELLIGIBLE)

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about less taxes, less regulations for the big corporations and for the rich, not for the working people? How about payments to a porn star and then lying about it? Hmm. Swamp-like behavior, seems to me.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Do you like -- you like the phrase?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, drain the swamp.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Even though it was taken right from Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Why not use MAGA?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump made it a hit. Drain the swamp.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So do you -- don't you think in terms of labeling and in terms of branding, don't you think that that ship has sailed?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Don't you think this is like Jiu-Jitsu, where you use your opponent's energy against him?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: "Karate Kid" is coming back, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. That's the only thing --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: We do not know if Ralph Macchio's still got it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. He's only 70.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So I think he can come back. The blue wave might be a blue grave the way they're headed. They've got no originality. I came up with some planks for them, the top Democratic ideas. Gang members are people, too. I think that should be -- Hamas are just victims of Zionism. Coffee shops make great homeless shelters. We're going to do that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Coming up later, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can spy on campaigns. And we liked it better when North Korea wanted us dead. See? Every time there's progress, the Democrats lose.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: ISIS flourishing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The more there is progress, the Dems lose. By the way, I have to defend Keith Ellison. I think he had a good -- he has a good voice.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was a talent show. I've see some Republicans in talent shows. Oh, man, pretty bad. But ridicule does feel good. It soothes your friends, but it's not a plank. Right now, the Democrats prefer to be the hecklers in the stands rather than being on the field. They're like the drunk guy screaming at the third base coach.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And it's been 18 months.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, they had --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They've got nothing.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That was very good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Brian.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: They had a slogan, "Better Deal."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It wasn't going anywhere, because Russia and impeachment took and swamped it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, no, absolutely. I mean, the Democrats are just guilty of plagiarism. They're trying to steal from President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Just like Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And they have no new ideas, and they're repeating it, trying to see if it can work for themselves. That just goes to show you, that's a party in disarray. They are completely disconnected from the voters once again. It didn't work with Hillary Clinton. And by the way, that wig looked more like Hillary Clinton. That's why I was confused. I was like --

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Right. It was confusing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And fine. So he can sing and dance, whatever. OK. That's perfect, because he might be needing to do that going forward, because I don't know if it's going to work out with lack of ideas for the DNC.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Well, and we're still in but two in three are happy with the economy. And overall, consumer confidence is up to a 17-year high. So these are positives. But as you know, if we were doing the show in January, we were wearing coats and he a little slow to get on, then it looked as though it was double digits.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you should check out retirements and fund-raising on the Democratic side. Looking good. But you know, Republicans.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Republicans have a ton of money. Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: All right. Twenty-six minutes before the top of the hour. Controversy is --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who are you?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: -- brewing over the Starbucks, over the change, "no purchase necessary" story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What are you, on radio?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Starbucks just announced a new policy that lets people hang out and use the bathroom without ever having to buy anything. This was their PR response to that big screw-up when two black men were arrested for hanging around in one cafe in Philly. Now, Starbucks, realizing they just sent an open invite to the nation's homeless, now says sleeping, drug or alcohol use will not be tolerated. So how will this work? Well, like panicky responses, the consequences won't be borne by the execs. The CEO won't be on the front lines. He'll be too busy monitoring his company's Twitter feed. Instead, baristas, people making far less money than the consultants, will be forced to ask other patrons if someone's behavior bothers them before taking action. So this whole thing is going to end up looking like a rerun from "COPS." And it puts pressure on employees and later the police will be blamed by both the unruly patrons and social justice warriors now present at these overpriced coffee temples. As you know, 8,000-plus locations will shut next Tuesday for unconscious bias training. I call it a 'woke-uccino.' Unconscious bias training. You see the trick there? If this is unconscious, how can you deny your bias? It's automatic and invisible, so you can't know you're a bigot. Only in today's PC's America could a coffeeshop decide that it's the moral conscience of the nation. So Starbucks, keep the new $7 Virtue Signal Vente. We drink coffee to be awake, not woke.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was a good one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That should be in your next book, Volume Two.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I have a book coming out now of monologues I'd like to share with society.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Get the full screen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, Juan, this puts the responsibility on the baristas, who just want to sell coffee. And they're going to end up being mental health professionals. In New York, there are people that are unstable who come into these places, and it can be pretty ugly. You can't put that kind of pressure on people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You are -- you're cranky today, so I'm going to forgive a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, he's got a sore throat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's got a sore throat?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We love you, but you're cranky today. So anyway, I just want to say, this is a rare moment when I agree with you, because I'm a regular Starbucks customer. And but the thing is, Greg, I go in and I get upset if I can't use the bathroom because it's occupied.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Or someone is in there for hours. But I also get upset when I can't find a place to sit or even stand, because guess what? It's not homeless people. But it's oftentimes young people. They've got their computers. They've got this and that. Now, I will say that -- So I get upset. But then I feel like, you know what? I am a privileged little snot, because my wife said to me and other people have said to me that Starbucks intentionally created a culture where they're a coffee shop. They are the so-called third place where you can meet your friends, where you can have debates, where you can work. And then all of a sudden, you say, "Well, but that guy looks kind of threatening or that guy looks like he's poor, and he can't be in here." Well, that's a contradiction. And then all of a sudden, you do get involved in, are those two guys who are asking to use the bathroom just bums or are they just two businessmen?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Hello, hello, hello. Two words. Dunkin' Donuts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There goes the sources (ph). Let me tell you, if they're going to act like this with the nonsense, so no one's trying to discriminate. Are you buying something in there? Do you have something you would like to purchase to stimulate the economy, or do you just want to come in and clogged the toilet and take all the tables? I've had it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, it's -- Brian, you can't -- imagine doing this at any restaurant, where you walk in and go, "I'm just going to hang out." You can't. You go to a Greek diner in midtown, they'll throw you out out.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: In another language.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's a restaurant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I will say this. This one, is this your best block in a long time. You're down three different roads, and I'm totally in -- I can't beat this. But I would say I -- fundamentally, I cannot use somebody's bathroom or get changed to pay a -- to pay a toll unless I buy something from that store. I just know that that's it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Your parents taught you that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: you just know it --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Isn't it courteous? Right? If you go in to use the 7-Eleven bathroom, and you know, buy a Snickers.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: By the way, the Starbucks -- the Starbucks and the Dunkin' Donuts have something in common. Their bathrooms are way too big. You can land a helicopter in them. You just need a small bathroom.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like the big bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You do?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There is going to be a lawsuit, just like, you know, somebody is going to be injured or stabbed and then that's it for this.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Or you woke up. Or you're going to have to make our own coffee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, Brian, there's somebody over here. This ain't no "FOX & Friends." All right? Dana, this is actually a failure of society and a way to figure out what to do with the homeless. This is, like, our Band-Aid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, a couple things. One, this falls into my P.R. law that every overreaction will cause an equal or greater overreaction.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That should be in your book.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And this was going to -- I'll write a new book, maybe. Put this back in there. I am for better and more public restrooms. OK? It doesn't have to be at somebody's private business. But if this private business decides that this is what it wants to do this, OK, knock yourselves out. But I would rather go to Dunkin'.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. There you go. I think we solved one of the world's greatest problems. Like Dunkin' Donuts. Maybe they will send us some stuff.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Before the show is over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I would like to make a suggestion for some Febreze in the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It just covers it up, Kimberly. Should bosses crack down on employees' obsessive cell phone use? Let's debate next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: New studies are revealing some shocking information about just how addicted we all are to our cell phones. A recent one finds that the average person touches, pokes, pinches and swipes their phone --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What do you mean, pinches?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- over 2,600 times a day. It's unbelievable. Because of this, one CEO is banning them in meetings, and others are trying to limit their employees' phone use. Now, we sit here at this desk. And there are four cell phones on the desk. Let me just tell you --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And an iPad.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So what do you think, Kimberly? It's a good idea to ban him?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, it makes sense. Right?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It does.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Because then you just can't reach out. You can't touch them. You can't, you know, resist the temptation. I don't know. I just like to get things done, organize, make lists, like always updating things. So I'm always trying to get something done. I don't like downtime too much. But yes, I think if you're in a meeting and pay attention, et cetera, then maybe it's like a good little line in a meeting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Brian, in fact, picking up on what Kimberly said, according to the studies, you have a lower level of cognitive performance if your mobile phone is on the desk.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: This is the biggest issue in America today, because everyone has a phone. No matter how rich or poor you are, everyone's got a phone, and it's distracting. It's like, hey, you guys are OK, but the people here are more important.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: And I think this boss is doing a great thing in all of them, he or she is, by allowing us -- making us put this away, so I have no choice. I will get in trouble if I put it away.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: By the way, you have two, all the time. On "FOX & Friends." All the time when I used to fill in for you.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Can I just be a commentator and not my personal life?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Your personal ---

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But it is -- but it is a problem, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I'll telling you, I would just wonder how many times I would use it, any of us would use it if we weren't in the news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Dana, so I learned a new word today. Nomo-phobia. Which means no mobile phones make you afraid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They like their --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You want your phone. You want to know what's going on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would say, if you're a recent graduate and you've just got a new job in the great new economy, if you want to get promoted, start today on the first job, do not take your cell phone to any meetings. Don't take it out. And you will be noticed, and it will be recognized.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is a very good tip for a minute.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: This is just going great, this block.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll put that in my yew book, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg, do you disagree?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. I -- there's research that shows, like, the brain's function is to be attentive. And you can try this anytime you want. Try to pay attention to more than one thing. It's impossible. It's why we get obsessed over things. If somebody introduces a thought into your head, you will think about it and you will not be able to think about anything else. You can say you're listening to your spouse while you're watching a game, but you're actually switching. It's imperceptible. But you're actually switching, and so you're actually missing out on important things. And this is actually pretty deadly. If you look at the -- as the stuff has come out with driving and texting, it's probably one of the most dangerous combinations you're going to find. And I don't know what -- what the numbers, but it's pretty close to --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What about you, show hosting and on Twitter?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Freaking out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I do it during break so I don't have to talk to you people.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Now we know how you really feel.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Can we stay on commercial break?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, we have "One More Thing" to make you laugh. That's next om "The Five."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing." We're going to skip Brian until the last one. You get to go first.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, thanks.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Payback.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? Life is full of surprises, and yesterday I got a happy one. It was a very proud moment when I learned that my biography of former Supreme Court justice Thurgood Marshall was named one of the 40 best biographies of all time --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- by BookClub.com.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So take a look at this classic C-SPAN interview I did 20 years ago, in 1998, when the book came out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I had a real privilege, Brian. I got to interview Marshall for a six-month period in 1989. This was at the end of his career, end of his life. It was a rich time, and one in which he was willing to talk. I felt -- you know, it's been a great gift for me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So the book has continued to steadily sell and was reissued for the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board. So for me, just on a personal basis, let me just say thank you and it's a thrill to be among America's greatest biographers. I can't believe it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm glad I could help you with that book.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The book's in the White House.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's really impressive, Juan. Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. I've got one. Too bad Jesse isn't here, because he would have been impressed with this one. All right. Mary Sedgwick, she's been legally blind since 2003, and she recently got the chance to see her guide dog for the first time, thanks to a pair of high-tech glasses.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And she shared the video of her very emotional moment. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: MARU SEDGWICK, LEGALLY BLIND
utterances.utterance: Lucy! Look at your eyes, Lucy! Oh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, those of us who are animal lovers -- and I don't mean MS-13 -- animal lovers will love that. She put in an online post that "There are no words to describe how I felt when I saw the face of my beloved family and friends and the beautiful soulful eyes of Lucy for the first time." She was a medical student, and she was -- she had dreams of being a doctor. In her fourth year at school, that was when her blindness began. But she says now, with these new glasses she hopes to return to work in the medical field. And we wish her a lot of luck.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is excellent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's a very moving moment. Very happy for her. So I have a very cute "One More Thing." And it's about seven Glenpool firefighters. And they welcomed new babies all within one year. Seven of Oklahoma's bravest not only battle the blazes but also change diapers and make bottles.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: In less than a year, seven out of the 20 from this Glenpool Fire Department in Glenpool, Oklahoma, as it turns out, became new dads. And so they decided to commemorate the special occasion with group photos that came from one of the firefighters' wives. So they waited for the last child to be born. So they go -- oldest is 15 months, youngest is four weeks. Obviously, was probably pretty difficult to get all those babies to be looking in the same direction at the same time. So congratulations to them. And God bless their families.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's a great story.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So cute, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. Now for actual news.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Cable News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Cable News." All right, as you know, CNN has been in a lot, a lot of ratings trouble. God knows what's going to happen to them. So they've decided -- they've decided -- CNN has decided to bring back "Crossfire" for the third time. And here's a clip. I've got a preview.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Which one's Tucker?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here we go. Here we go. I'm telling you, you put this on at 8 p.m., CNN, you're going to get huge ratings. So don't keep it at 5. Put it at 8.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's not going to work, because they don't have Tucker Carlson.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Well, let's talk greatness. Let's talk soccer. First off, Cristiano Rinaldo, he is the best player, maybe, in the world today. Everyone laughed when they looked at his bust. They said, "What are you doing? Are you mocking him? And I thought that was as lowest they can go. And now comes -- now comes Brandi Chastain. Remember Brandi Chastain, one of the finest women soccer players ever? Eight-eight caps. Excuse me, 192 caps, on the national team from '88 to 2004.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We don't know what that means.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That means playing in the national -- in the national game. Well, she's so great, they put her into the Bay Area Sports Hall of Fame. That's the good news.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But look at the picture.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, that's not her.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That is her. Sometimes it's better not to be great if that's how you're going to be depicted for all time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, you could draw her better on the back of your folder. Than that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: People say that might be Babe Ruth on a bad day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Brandi Chastain is a beautiful woman.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's not very nice.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: She demands better.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's not very nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They should redo that.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's so great not to be great because no one will ever do that for me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
